Detection of process launches or modific.Data: Windows Event ID 4688, Windows Event ID 4657
Detection of process launches or modific.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 for process creations with command-line arguments or parent-child relationships indicative of UAC bypass. Monitor Windows Event ID 4657 for changes to specific user-accessible Registry keys known to be involved in UAC bypass methods. Use correlation analysis to link suspicious process creation events with preceding registry modifications.

Execution of privilege escalation comman.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 and Zeek software.log for command lines containing 'sudo' or other known privilege escalation tools/commands. Look for process creations with command lines that indicate execution as root or another privileged user. Use frequency analysis on command execution per user to identify unusual spikes or rare users executing privilege escalation commands.

Loading of unsigned or unusual DLLs by p.Action: Analyze Windows Event ID 7 (Sysmon Image Loaded) logs. Filter events where the process path corresponds to a process running with elevated privileges. Check the 'Signed' field. Identify unsigned DLLs loaded by these processes. Use frequency analysis to identify rare or newly observed unsigned DLLs loaded by privileged processes across the environment.

Process injection or suspicious process.Data: Windows Event ID 8, Windows Event ID 10, Windows Event ID 4688
Process injection or suspicious process.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 8 (Sysmon CreateRemoteThread) and Windows Event ID 10 (Sysmon ProcessAccess) for source processes with elevated privileges. Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 for child processes spawned by parent processes with elevated privileges. Identify suspicious relationships or target processes (e.g., injecting into explorer.exe from a service process). Apply correlation analysis to link injection/spawning events to potentially malicious code execution or defensive countermeasure attempts.
